content.text: As a new BPUAA user, it is a good idea to familiarize yourself with the following information.

BPUAA is a high-performance, multi-tier, web based application that is deployed on commodity based enterprise linux servers. The application server is cluster-able using redundant servers providing a highly-available configuration.
BPUAA requires a modern x86 or x86-64 server architecture such as Intel Xeon or AMD Opteron. All server vendors are supported, but typically BPUAA is deployed on Dell PowerEdge or Sun Netra servers.

BPUAA is a next generation customer–centric service assurance system specifically designed to manage complex networks of heterogeneous devices. It uses the latest advancements in computing hardware and software design to provide unprecedented performance and scalability while being easy to configure and manage. BPUAA provides a rich–set of service assurance features including -
BPUAA is a pure web based client–server application. There is no client software the user must install on the client machine except for a 100% standards compliant browser.
We recommend using Google Chrome for accurate page rendering.
Before starting with BPUAA, you might want to explore it's key features and how things work .

Fault Management is the set of functions that detect, isolate and help to troubleshoot the issues in a network. It also includes maintaining and examining error logs, accepting and acting on error detection notifications, tracing and identifying faults, carrying out sequences of diagnostics tests, correcting faults, reporting error conditions, and localizing and tracing faults.

A fault management identifies events and automatically take action, either by launching a program or a script to take corrective action, or activating notification software that allows the network operator to take proper intervention (For example, send e-mail or SMS text to a mobile phone).
BPUAA fault management provides comprehensive monitoring, correlation and consolidation across any size or type of network infrastructure.
Network operators, users and administrators have the ability to configure their views of network alarms, topology maps and reports to customize it to their current needs.
Performance management helps in anomaly detection using baselining normal performance and configuration of thresholds.

Blue Planet Performance Management is a comprehensive, configurable software application that provides network performance monitoring, analysis, and visualization to proactively identify and notify network operators of potential problems, allowing them to optimize resources and plan operations for maximizing ROI and network performance.
A node is a network element. Some common examples of nodes are routers, switches, hubs, repeaters, cable modems and CMTS equipment.

Resource Adapters (RAs) collect real-time, multisource telemetry and assurance data and provide the interface between the network and UAA platform. Our RAs support over 1,300 products across more than 135 vendors today, and those numbers are growing.
Service assurance provides dynamic service visualization and modeling of relationships between application, physical, and virtual components.

Blue Planet Service Assurance is an analytics software application auto-discovers network services from a variety of sources and maps the service hierarchy regardless of vendor or technology, allowing it to self-update and maintain service topology.
MEF Y.1731 compliant ethernet service monitoring with customer impact analysis.
Blue Planet Ethernet Assurance is a standards-compliant solution that provides unprecedented visualization and proactive SLA monitoring of Ethernet services to ensure and improve customer experience.

An alarm can be defined as a notification to network operator when there is a problem or failure in a device or a service in the network. Alarms might require an operator's action in case if there is an issue to be fixed.

Alarm customization assists in Root Cause Analysis (RCA) used for identifying the root causes of faults or problems. Using this technique user can understand which events/traps/alarms indicate root cause or “hard” failures in the network.

Resource Adapter (RA) customization as part of alarm customization is defined as the ability to customize any alarm attribute and/or change the alarm mapping after it has been normalized by a profile or Resource Adapter, before it is passed to the alarm manager.

Part of Alarm customization, is Alarm Correlation Policy (ACP) which enables the Network Operations Center (NOC) employees to correlate the alarms of certain pattern, and show a single alarm which can represent the root cause problem in a better way.

The BPUAA Dashboard feature provides a customizable user interface that is capable of displaying, in real–time, alarm, performance, topology information as well as external web applications. In addition it can be customized by job function, technology, network segment or any other criteria.
Dashboards save time by providing views of most recent information from a single point of view. Examples include -

BPUAA maintains a pooled, reusable set of database connections to a remote database. An advance report provides the ability to query a remote database using the pooled database connection. Generated reports can be exported in Comma Separated Value (CSV) file format.

BPUAA can automatically discover nodes upon user initiated discovery action and add them to the discovery table. If your network has a large number of nodes supporting standard communication protocols like SNMP and TL1, using discovery can be an efficient way to add them to the network view.

Even though Nodes can be added manually, it may be beneficial to use a discovery task to add even a single node. One of the benefits of discovery is that BPUAA will populate some node properties learned during the discovery process. These are -

The workflow feature is used to automate certain actions that may be applied to Network or Service Alarms. A well designed collection of Workflows can help NOC personnel organize and prioritize incoming alarms, and remove the burden of manually performing common, routine actions.
Some of these actions could be -
alarms are raised, or remain standing for a specified period
Few more to add are Import and Export feature, creating custom fields for Alarms, Nodes and EndPoints, Integration of internal and external trouble ticketing systems, Nodes Actions etc.
Users can read and learn about these utilities in detail from respective chapters in the user guide.

can parse the incoming log messages received from the devices such as syslog to create specific name fields from logs that can be used in alarm property to raise alarms set in the translator. These translators can be assigned to the Resource Adapters.
BPUAA allows seamless integration with other Blue Planet Software, Inc. products such as SDWAN/MDSO, NFVO, various TMF APIs, ROA, and BPI.
Users can refer to the BPUAAAdministration Guide to learn more about the above features.

All Blue Planet Software, Inc. products use Flexera Licensing software. The administrators are required to setup and install different feature and RA licenses for the BPUAA to work. Users can read more about the Flexera Licensing and how to setup licensing server from the BPUAAinstall-ation document.
Light weight data collector (LWDC) supports management of devices with different IP addresses and poll from other sites such as, government agencies, where you can deploy a remote collector.
LWDC can also manage companies with the same instance, where the LWDC need to be in the other network.
The REST APIs provide programmatic read and write access to BPUAA operations on Inventory Objects, Fault etc. These APIs allow users to perform CRUD operation on the inverntory and Alarm data.
To access, learn more about BPUAA REST API, login to BPUAA as a user having security admin or sysadmin privileges. From the App Bar UI, navigate to System > Platform and select Swagger UI.
BPUAA creates logs at each level of installation/use of the software for ease of troubleshooting by the system admins and support team.

Should you know all the concepts and definitions or just few? How does this feature works? What kind of relationship it has with other BPUAA's features? What are common activities you can perform on Alarms and Events page?
The Alarms and Events feature in BPUAA allows you to view and manage network and service alarms. This feature is one of the extensively used features in BPUAA.
The Alarms and Events feature allows you to view and manage network and service alarms. This feature is one of the extensively used features in BPUAA.
Alarms and Events feature can achieve -

Fault Management is the set of functions that detect, isolate and help to troubleshoot the issues in a network. It also includes maintaining and examining error logs, accepting and acting on error detection notifications, tracing and identifying faults, carrying out sequences of diagnostics tests, correcting faults, reporting error conditions, and localizing and tracing faults.

A fault management identifies events and automatically take action, either by launching a program or a script to take corrective action, or activating notification software that allows the network operator to take proper intervention (For example, send e-mail or SMS text to a mobile phone).
BPUAA fault management provides comprehensive monitoring, correlation and consolidation across any size or type of network infrastructure.
Network operators, users and administrators have the ability to configure their views of network alarms, topology maps and reports to customize it to their current needs.

An alarm can be defined as a notification to network operator when there is a problem or failure in a device or a service in the network. Alarms might require an operator's action in case if there is an issue to be fixed.
An alarm indicating that the battery of a device is low and needs a power source.
In BPUAA an alarm is classified into -
Events represent normal system status messages and do not require an operator action. An event is defined as a detectable occurrence, which may or may not be associated with an alarm.
Login and Logout, State changes, System heartbeats etc.
This section provides a detailed list of alarm objects and their definition.

An event is an object created by BPUAA to represent a fault indication. Events represent the raise or clearing of conditions on the node. BPUAA uses events to consolidate vendor and protocol specific fault indications into a common format.
A standing condition is one that remains in effect until explicitly cleared.
Another name for the standing condition.
A transient condition is one that is, by design, never cleared. An example of this is system heartbeat messages. Transient conditions are not normally considered alarms.

When an alarm is deferred, BPUAA removes it from the active alarm list. Alarms may be deferred for a defined period. The deferment is temporary: a deferred alarm will re–appear after its deferment period has expired.
You can view all the deferred alarms by selecting the All Alarms check box.
The priority of an alarm is determined by NOC personnel defined priorities are -

Priority may be used to organize alarms into categories based on the importance of the alarm. Priorities may be assigned or changed manually by NOC personnel or automatically by BPUAA’s workflow engine.
The severity of an alarm is determined by the node and represents the node’s assessment of the importance of the alarm. BPUAA may be configured to reassign severity.
The alarm source is the entity that is raising the alarm. It is usually an equipment or facility identifier. In the case of TL1, the Aid is the alarm source.
A network alarm is one that is reported by a node.

A security or system alarm is a standing condition generated by BPUAA. these alarms are raised by BPUAA’s security module to report system conditions such as user lockouts due to excessive invalid login attempts or problems with database operations such as a backup failure.
An End Point is an internal object that represents an alarm source. It is used by BPUAA to associate the alarm source with a service.

A service is an abstract alarm source, defined by a collection of end points against which service alarms may be raised. the primary purpose of service definitions is to organize and consolidate network alarms.

Alarm suppression is the act of hiding network and service alarms from the operator’s view. Alarm suppression is used to remove symptomatic alarms from the active and service alarm lists to more clearly reveal the root cause(s) of network problems. Suppressed alarms are not removed from the alarm database; they are merely hidden from view and may be restored using the Show: suppressed control. Alarm suppression is described in detail in Alarm Suppression Policies under Service.

Alarm thresholds are used to soak and the–bounce network alarms. BPUAA supports both raise and clear thresholds. thresholds are fine grained; they may be tailored to individual end points. Alarm thresholds are described in detail in Alarm threshold Policies.
List of alarm objects and their definition

RCA is calculated based on the alarm classifications. Following is the list of the available classifications -
Alarms with the following classifications can never be a root cause alarm as these classifications will not be the main cause for any type of failures -

All other classifications would become root cause, if there are no other highest classification alarm present in the same Endpoint/Service. If there are two alarms with the same highest classification, both the alarms remains an independent alarm.

If there are multiple alarms with same classification on dependent objects (like parent-child Endpoint or service-service segments), they will be correlated to the one on the highest level (like Parent in Endpoint case and bottom most segment in Service case).
Following are the various root cause methods used to correlate the alarms -
The goal of same object suppression is to suppress lower classification alarms if possible on any given object such as source.
For example, if there is a LINKDOWN alarm (which is a direct failure indication) along with four other indeterminate alarms on ETH1 then the four other alarms should be suppressed by the LINKDOWN.
The goal is to suppress alarms on connected interfaces/services so that only a single alarm indication appears.
If there is a node failure alarm on one source and equipment failure on the other, the equipment alarm gets suppressed with node failure alarm and gets correlated to node failure alarm.

This type of suppression considers the object graph. When there is a root-cause failure (such as card failure) then all objects dependent upon that object (such as cards ports, interfaces, vLans, and so on) can be related to the card failure and suppressed. This can be applied to OpenStack nodes dependencies.
After the system default root cause analysis logic, if required user can change the root cause alarm manually based on the requirement.

Earlier only network alarms were persisted in graph db and to support graph based correlation, added support to persist service/correlated_service alarm in the graph DB/neo4j for following use cases -

When CORRELATED_SERVICE_ALARM is generated from RAISE_A_NEW_SERVICE_ALARM ACP, there is a chance of conflict between Alarm Correlation Policy and Root Cause Analysis, due to which service alarm and network alarm may get related to each other
All the service synched from ROA are persisted as connections in BPUAA and no such limitation is expected.
For Non-ROA case, the above scenario maybe is a limitation.

The Root Cause Analysis (RCA) is a process that correlates the alarms being raised in the network (based on certain rules and the alarms' classification/severity), and show a single alarm which can represent the root cause problem in a better way. Operationally one of the events to occur in a group of correlated events is likely to be the root-cause (other events are cascading symptoms). This feature helps to suppress those symptom alarms.
RCA is applicable to both network and service alarms.

Periodically, the system scans the active alarms list and correlates them. The RCA policies are evaluated from highest priority to lowest-priority. A high priority RCA can override the alarm correlated by a low priority RCA based on priority of applied RCA Rule and classification.

header: Factors considered while choosing a Root Cause alarm

content.text: If multiple alarms satisfy the rules defined by a particular RCA, the root-cause is chosen based on following factors:
content.header: Factors considered while choosing a Root Cause alarm

content.text: It is a beta version alarm field, used for dev debug purpose only. We may see inconsistent values in few corner cases.
The order of alarm classification is as follows -
Always Parent EP alarm becomes root cause if it's classification higher or equal priority than child EP alarm, otherwise correlation will not happen.
IMMD_ EP_ NA_ WITH_ LNKD_ PRNT_ EP_ NA_ BY_SVC
This is a scenario based RCA. For more details go to respective RCA details. If there are 2 nodes with a linked service b/w one of their endpoints.
If there is ep alarm on first node and ep alarm on other node's linked Parent endpoint. Linked parent EP can be at any level.
immediate endpoint n/w alarm with n/w alarm on linked EP's parent endpoint
This is a scenario based RCA. For more details go to respective RCA details.
If there are 2 nodes with a linked service b/w one of their endpoints. If there is ep alarm on first node and ep alarm on other node's node endpoint. It is similar to IMMD_EP_NA_WITH_
with assumption that node-endpoint is the parent of all endpoint.
immediate endpoint n/w alarm with node alarm on the linked EP's node endpoint
This is special case of RCA where
Details about each RCA Rule in the order of execution
1. NA_PER_EP / RCA 1 (Correlate Network Alarms Per Endpoint)
Equipment / Network alarms raised on the same endpoint, are correlated together.
2. NA_PER_RELATED_EPS / RCA 2 (Correlate Network Alarms Per Related Endpoints (i.e. across Parent-Child Relationship Hierarchy of Endpoints))
3. NA_PER_SVC / RCA 3.1 (Correlate Network Alarms Per Service)

Consider 2 EPs connected by a service - they get correlated with each other (which of them becomes Root Cause, is decided on the basis of classification, severity and sequence number (received-time)).
Here, Ports A-P1 and B-P4 are connected by a service segment called 'svc-segment-1'.
4. SA_PER_SVC / RCA 3.2 (Correlate Service Alarms Per Service)
Different alarms raised on a service are correlated together
5. SA_WITH_NA_PER_SVC / RCA 3.3 (Correlate Service Alarms With Network Alarms Per Service)
Service alarm is correlated under its immediate equipment alarm
Here, Ports A-P1 and B-P4 are connected by svc-segment-1.
IMMD_ EP_ NA_ WITH_ LNKD_ PRNT_ EP_ NA_ BY_ SVC/ RCA 3.4 (Correlate Immediate Endpoint Network Alarm on a Service, With the Alarm on a Parent Endpoint indirectly Linked to that Service)
Consider 2 different nodes A and B.
Correlate Immediate Endpoint Network Alarm on a Service, With the Alarm on a Parent Endpoint indirectly Linked to that Service
Node A has a card endpoint C1 on it, and this card has a port endpoint P1 on it. Similarly, node B has a card endpoint C2 on it with a port endpoint P2 on it.
Nodes A and B are related to each other through a service called service 1.
If card C1 on node A goes down, even though alarm is not raised on its immediate port P1, since it is connected to node B via service relation, port endpoint P2 on node B goes down.
Now the port EP alarm on node B should be suppressed under card EP alarm on node A.
Here default parent-child EP levels considered is 10, if a given customer n/w has more than 10 levels of parent-child EP levels this can be updated to higher value. Please refer configurations
7. NA_AND_SA_PER_PS_INCS_HRCHY / RCA 4.1 (Correlate Network Alarms and Service Alarms Per 'Protected Service-Included Service' Hierarchy)
Correlates all alarms that belong to all included services that are related to protected service via included_service upto 15 levels.
As the protected service depends on its included services, first we get the included services and then its higher level services while correlating.

When Alarm is raised on Active / Stand by service under a protected service and Main service is not affected, Endpoint under the included services will be the root cause alarm & affected service alarm will be correlated to it.

When Alarm is raised on Active / Stand by service under a protected service and Main service is affected(service alarm raised on main service), Endpoint under the included services will be the root cause alarm & affected service alarms will be correlated to it.

When both active & standby services under protected service are down (having alarms) and effects the Main service with an alarm, Latest EP alarm of an included service will be the root cause alarm & service alarm will be correlated to it. other (either active/protected) service alarm will be correlated under its associated EP alarm OR EP under Main service has alarm it will be correlated to latest down root cause EP alarm.
When Service Path is down later Service 4 is down, followed by Fully Protected Main Service Down
When Service 4 is down later Service Path is down, followed by Fully Protected Main Service Down
When Active Service is down, later Standby Service followed by Main service down
When Standby Service is down, later Active Service followed by Main service down
8. NA_AND_SA_PER_SVC_SEG_HRCHY / RCA 4.2 (Correlate Network Alarms and Service Alarms Per Service-Segment Hierarchy)
Correlate all alarms that belong to all services that are related together via dependencies/dependents up to 15 levels.
This value is configurable please refer configurations section for more details

As the service depends on its segments (unlike ep-ep relation where children depends on parent), first get the segments and then its higher level services while correlating, if the service has two segments then the higher service alarm will be correlated under segment alarm which has highest classification.
9. IMMD_ EP_ NA_ WITH_ LNKD_ NODE_ ALRM_ BY_ SVC / RCA 4.3 (Correlate Immediate Endpoint Network Alarm on a Service, With the Alarm on a Node indirectly Linked to that Service)
Say, 2 endpoints Port A-P1 and Port B-P2 (belonging to different nodes A & B respectively) are connected through service segment.
Node A goes down, (and though alarm not raised on A-P1 but), through the service connection, also causes B-P2 to go down.
Hence, B-P2 alarm should correlate under Node A (parent node of A-P1, having an alarm).
There is no alarm on Node A's cards/ports. This comes from an example where node has completely failed.
Consider a hierarchy, where few node endpoints are related by ‘:previous_hop’ relationship.
11. EP_NA_WITH_CORRESP_NODE_ALRM/ RCA 6 (Correlate Endpoint Network Alarms With Corresponding Node Alarm)

This is special RCA, if there is an COMM/REACHABILITY alarm on node, then all the unsuppressed ep alarms per node will be correlated under the COMM/REACHABILITY alarm, if its classification is higher or equals to ep alarm.
In other words it's similar to RCA2 (parent-child) assuming node ep is the parent of all other eps on the node.
Its an old existing alarms in the system

A Cloud interface allows an user to monitor cloud computing systems such as OpenStack and VMware.
Cloud computing is a type of Internet-based computing that relies on sharing computing resources rather than having local servers or personal devices to handle applications, on demand.

Cloud computing has become a highly demanding service or utility due to the advantages of high computing power, cheap cost of services, high performance, scalability, accessibility as well as availability. It focuses primarily on optimization of the network services.
Using BPUAA, you can monitor cloud computing system such as OpenStack and VMware.

BPUAA offers holistic assurance of NFV and SDN assets and enables businesses to successfully operationalize virtual network investments. BPUAA monitors the application, virtual, physical components independently and dynamically models the relationships between them providing a complete picture of how a disaggregated function is performing. BPUAA offers comprehensive capabilities to handle the volatility and elastic nature of cloud and SDN infrastructure. BPUAA complements orchestration and completes the stack with a feedback loop into orchestration and cloud controllers.

BPUAA automation provides dynamic, automated actions to root-cause issues. It provides feedback to orchestration, cloud, and SDN controllers so that failed or poor performing virtual services can be re-mediated or optimized.
The Cloud menu has the following structure -
Compute nodes run the virtual machine instances in OpenStack/VMware. These nodes receive requests from the controller node.

A compute node manages the life cycle of compute instances in a Data center environment. Responsibilities of a compute node include spawning, scheduling and decommissioning of virtual machines on demand.

A controller is a physical server. The cloud controller provides the central management system for OpenStack deployments. Typically, the cloud controller manages authentication and sends messaging to all the systems through a message queue. For many deployments, the cloud controller is a single node.
The cloud controller manages the following services for the cloud -
The controllers / compute hosts that are discovered on BPUAA can be viewed on this page.
One controller can have many compute nodes.
The Compute service relies on a hypervisor to run virtual machine instances. OpenStack can use various hypervisors.
A hypervisor provides software to manage virtual machine access to the underlying hardware. The hypervisor creates, manages, and monitors virtual machines.
Clicking the Name of any compute Node/Controller, displays the

A virtual machine (VM) is an Operating System (OS) or application environment that is installed on software which imitates dedicated hardware. The end user has the same experience on a virtual machine as they would have on dedicated hardware.
Specialized software called a hypervisor emulates the PC client or server's CPU, memory, hard disk, network and other hardware resources completely, enabling virtual machines to share the resources.
All virtual machines (VM) and details of virtual machines that are discovered on BPUAA can be viewed from this page.
All VMs belonging to an OpenStack get inventoried once the controller is added to BPUAA.

In a Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) architecture, a Virtualized Network Function (VNF), is responsible for handling specific network functions that run in one or more virtual machines on top of the hardware networking infrastructure. VNF can include routers, switches, servers, and more.
NFV came into picture in order to reduce -

The VNF Hosts such as routers, switches, operating systems in the openstack system get inventoried once the controller is added toBPUAA. All the inventoried VNF hosts and their information such as name, availability, Operational state and so on can be viewed on VNFs page.
Virtual Network Function (VNF) is a service between two or more VNF nodes. All these VNFs can be viewed on this page.

An Ethernet Assurance offers service providers a rich user interface with the ability to see the current status of services at-a-glance.
Ethernet is a terminology used for extensions to Ethernet to enable telecommunications network providers to provide Ethernet services to customers and to utilize Ethernet technology in the networks.
The Ethernet is used to achieve end-to-end service manageability. The model for Ethernet service is designed by Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF).
With BPUAA Ethernet Assurance, service providers can -
BPUAA Ethernet Assurance offers service providers a rich user interface with the ability to see the current status of services at-a-glance.

NOC engineers can set escalating thresholds for progressive alarming as network congestion or utilization increases, enabling a proactive approach to preventing the customer experience from degrading.

The platform meanwhile provides advanced, customized and scheduled reports that provide information from the BPUAA Ethernet Assurance platform along with data from external systems, offering powerful and consolidated views across the network and OSS infrastructure.

BPUAA Ethernet Assurance also includes enhanced SLA management to meet the needs of next-generation services, with the ability to map operational performance to customer services, to clearly show the impact of network degradation and process faults on contracted SLAs. BPUAA was designed specifically to address the multi-vendor reality of today’s service provider networks. By leveraging key industry standards such as MEF, IEEE 802.1ag and ITU Y.1731, BPUAA can be deployed to support performance monitoring and reporting of services across multi-vendor networks.

Ethernet Virtual Connection (EVC) is a logical representation of an Ethernet service as defined by the association between two or more User Network Interfaces (UNIs). An EVC establishes a communication relationship between one or more UNIs.
An EVC represents an Ethernet service and is an entity that provides an end-to-end connection between two or more customer end points.
BPUAA supports point-to-point EVC. Point-to-point EVC supports communication between only two UNIs. This type of EVC operates similar to a virtual circuit.

In BPUAA, it is possible to relate the state of independent events to the state of EVC. EVC state is updated from state change alarms. For example, EVC state "Down" means the EVC is unavailable. Timestamp of the alarm is used to calculate the availability of EVC.

Metrics are available for state up-time, state downtime and availability of EVC, which are used to calculate EVC availability. All these three types of metrics have to be assigned to EVC to calculate the availability.

IP-SLA is a decentralized and distributed way of managing networks by embedding performance collection capabilities in network devices. With IP-SLA, network devices perform traffic monitoring activities with each other. Thus avoiding the need for the NMS to maintain expensive long-distance paths of communication with each monitored network device.
BPUAA leverages the Cisco's IP-SLA technology. IP-SLA is embedded as a capability in the Cisco IOS software, which is the software only in the Cisco's network devices.

IP-SLA Agents initiate IP-SLA tests to a remote responder, and IP-SLA responders respond to the request. A particular agent can have multiple IP-SLA tests running too many remote responders. A particular router/switch can be both an agent and a responder. For each IP-SLA test that has been configured, the agent collects edge-to-edge network performance information and stores it in the Cisco RTTMON MIB.

By specifying the IP address or an IP range, devices with IP-SLA configuration can be discovered by BPUAA. BPUAA checks for the following IP-SLA operations on a network device. After discovering these operations, BPUAA polls this device for information at regular intervals.

The IP-SLA Operations page displays IP-SLA operations being managed by BPUAA. IP-SLA capable nodes perform IP-SLA operations. BPUAA monitors such nodes on a periodic basis. The information retrieved from them are displayed on the Operations page in a tabular format.

content.text: Hop count is used to measure the number of hops a node/end point is connected to other nodes/endpoints. BPUAA supports three hop levels to view the node/endpoint connection.
You can increase or decrease the hop count by using the slider that appears when the Hop-Count button is clicked in the Toolbar.

The node/endpoint context in which the details page is opened will be applied for the hop count irrespective of the node/endpoint selection. To view different node/endpoint hop count navigate to the respective details pages.

Here, let's discuss on how you can add or edit a Node to enrich the network alarms, get comprehensive view of devices etc.
UAA does not allow user to create duplicate nodes, it will throw an error pop-up mentioning "
Node with specified IP and Port already exists
". 2 nodes are termed as duplicate if they have same IP and Port. However, in some cases user is allowed to create duplicate nodes:
If the protocol is TL1, then node with same IP and Port can be created if they have different names(TID). This can be avoided by configuring the TL1 nodes in the Gateway-Subtended configuration.

If the protocol is None and the parent Node is also set then user is allowed to create the node with same IP and Port. None protocol nodes in general are created to represent a process in a VM so we expect another VM node to have same IP.
If the site is different, user is allowed to create node with same IP and Port.

Some nodes may not allow direct authentication with a node’s agent. These nodes require that a chat session first be established, after which the agent session is established, usually by running some local command or program on

Some nodes require that a telnet session be established, after which a local command is used to access the node’s TL1 agent. Regardless of how this preliminary connection is established, it is called the chat, and usually requires a login id and password.
The actual connection procedures are vendor–specific and are handled by BPUAA. This Boolean property indicates that a chat session must be established before an agent login attempt is made.

In standard TL1, the data forwarding character is the semi–colon ( ; ). That is, a TL1 command should be processed as soon as the ( ; ) is entered. Some TL1 agents, however, do not process the command unless it is followed by CR (carriage return), LF(line–feed), or both.

Also, if a chat session is in use, it may buffer characters and require the CR/LF to forward the buffer (containing the command) on to the agent. If this value is true, BPUAA will append CR LF to all TL1 commands.

Blue Planet recommends changing all the required nodes into unmanaged state before deleting nodes, else the deletion of required nodes might result into partial deletion of the nodes due to the existence of few managed nodes.

While deleting a node, the confirmation dialogue box also contains a checkbox to delete all endpoints of the node being deleted which will become orphaned once the node is deleted. User can select/un-select the checkbox to delete the endpoints along with deleting the nodes as per their requirement.

Similarly, if the user is deleting a subnet with nodes and endpoints associated to it, 3 checkboxes to delete all child nodes, endpoints, and discovery tasks of the subnet being deleted. User can select/un-select the checkboxes to delete the nodes, endpoints along with deleting the subnet as per their requirement.
This section provides a detailed list of terms and their definition.

Nodes are associated with a connection type. A node’s connection type may be one of Direct, Gateway, Manager, Subtended, or Passive. This document will refer to the Gateway and Subtended connection types.
A Gateway node, or GNE, is a network element that provides access to Subtended network elements. A Gateway is reachable with an IP address and port.
